answers: holy fools [or fools for Christ; or salos; or yurodivy; prompt on fools]
parts: Name these ascetic figures of Eastern Orthodoxy. Their patron saint is Simeon, and St. Basil's Cathedral is named after a prominent one.
St. Basil's Cathedral is located in this city, where Patriarch Kirill leads as primate of the Russian Orthodox Church.

This group of conservatives left the Russian Orthodox Church in 1666 after objecting to reforms made by the Patriarch Nikon. The Lykov (LICK-uff) family, who isolated themselves in Siberia, were from this group.

answers: neuroplasticity [or neuronal plasticity; or brain plasticity]
functional magnetic resonance imaging [or fMRI; or functional MRI; prompt on MRI or magnetic resonance imaging]
savants [or autistic savants; or savant syndrome] <Mehr>
parts: Thorsten Fehr's experiment with a mathematical calculation prodigy found that his ability was not related to innate structural differences in the brain, but to this faculty in which the brain undergoes changes throughout one's life due to increased synaptic connections.
Fehr and others have conducted research on prodigies using this procedural technique. It measures brain activity by detecting blood flow in different regions.
Prodigies are distinct from these types of people, whose extreme activities come at a developmental cost. A notable example of these people is Kim Peek, who was fictionalized in Rain Man.

answers: slack key [accept slack-key guitar; accept kī hōʻalu; prompt on open tuning]
parts: Name this small instrument with four strings. It is based on the cavaquinho (kuh-vuh-KEEN-yoo) or the machete (muh-SHET-chee) that Portuguese immigrants brought to Hawai'i.

This simpler guitar tuning style, so named because both E string pegs were often lowered to D, became popular in the Hawai'ian Renaissance. In this style's taro patch tuning, the open strings form a major chord, while in its wahine (wa-HEE-nay) tuning, they form a major seventh chord.

Many Hawai'ian songs use this high vocal register, which alternates with chest voice in yodeling. Tiny Tim used it in "Tiptoe Through The Tulips," and a solo tenor uses it in Carmina Burana to depict a roasting swan.

answers: The Golden Ass [or Asinus aureus; or The Metamorphoses]
parts: Name this novel whose protagonist, Lucius, ends up in numerous comedic situations after accidentally transforming himself into the title beast.
Apuleius's The Golden Ass is the only ancient Roman novel written in this language that survives in its entirety.
At the end of the novel, Lucius, after being restored to human form, gratefully becomes a member of the cult of this divine being, who uses the local name "Campensis."

answers: lipoproteins [or apolipoproteins; prompt on LDL, HDL, IDL, or VLDL; prompt on lipids]
parts: Name this molecule whose side chain cleavage yields pregnenolone (preg-NEN-alone).

Cholesterol is transported in the blood as part of these complexes that consist of phospholipids and proteins like Apo E and B. Chylomicrons (ky-lo-MY-crons) are an ultra-low-density form of these particles.
Chylomicrons carry fats from the lacteals (LACK-tee-ulls) of this system to the blood. White blood cells are concentrated in this system's nodes.

answers: Victor Frankenstein [or Victor; or Dr. Frankenstein]
parts: Name this character who tells his story to Walton while dying at the North Pole. He had journeyed there in an obsessive quest to hunt down the fiend who murdered his bride-to-be, Elizabeth.
This author, who used the war between the Guelphs and the Ghibellines as the backdrop of her novel Valperga, wrote Frankenstein.

Shelley conceived of Frankenstein after Lord Byron challenged his guests to write ghost stories. This other guest responded to that challenge by writing "The Vampyre," the first published modern vampire story.

answers: temperance [or prohibition; accept synonyms such as being anti-alcohol]
parts: Name this social cause. Later in the century, it was promoted by the WCTU.
Barnum is better known as a showman and for being erroneously credited with saying that there is one of these types of people "born every minute."
This creature displayed by Barnum was supposedly a beast with the head of a monkey and the tail of a fish. Attractions purporting to be this thing were popular at carnivals.

Identify this type of prime number p such that two-p-plus-one is also prime. They were introduced by their namesake French mathematician in her attempts to prove Fermat's last theorem for certain exponents.

Germain primes share a conjectured density with these pairs of primes that differ by exactly 2, like 5 and 7. A famous open conjecture states that there are infinitely many of this type of prime, which was supported by a 2013 paper by Yitang Zhang (EE-tong JONG).

In response to Zhang's work, Terence Tao launched the 8th edition in this series of openly collaborative mathematical research projects, which proved that infinitely many pairs of primes differed by at most 4,680.

answers: Conservative Party [or Conservative and Unionist Party]
parts: Name this former owner of Harrods Department Store who embarrassed the John Major ministry in the aforementioned scandal. His eldest son died in a Paris car accident in 1997, which this man has occasionally blamed on the royal family.
Both John Major and his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, were members of this political party.

In another scandal during the Major ministry, Jonathan Aitken sued this newspaper over corruption allegations, but he was himself imprisoned for perjury. More recently, Edward Snowden leaked the existence of the PRISM surveillance program to this paper.

answers: Alexander von Humboldt [or Friedrich Wilhelm Heinrich Alexander von Humboldt]
Argentina [or Argentine Republic; or República Argentina] <Shimizu>
parts: Name this crop whose leaves are dipped in boiling water to make a popular South American tea-like drink.

Paraguayan leader José Gaspar Rodríguez de Francia raided the yerba mate plantation of Aimé Bonpland, this explorer's partner. This explorer came within a thousand feet of scaling Ecuador's Chimborazo in 1802.

This country's northeastern province of Misiones, which includes Iguazu Falls on its border with Brazil, is home to many yerba mate plantations. This country's plains are inhabited by ranchers called gauchos.

answers: Darcy–Weisbach equation [prompt on partial answer; do not accept or prompt on "Darcy's law"]
parts: Name this equation that gives the pressure loss due to friction in a given length of pipe. For turbulent flow, the friction factor can be determined using the Colebrook–White equation.
The Darcy–Weisbach equation is applicable for flows that are fully developed, steady, and also have this property. For a flow of this type, the divergence of the fluid velocity is zero.

For a pipe in which this value is significant, the Darcy friction factor can be found using a Moody diagram. This value quantifies how much the normal vector of a surface deviates from its ideal form.

answers: comic books [accept any kind of comics]
parts: Name these things that were attacked as harmful to children in the book Seduction of the Innocent, which alleged they promoted violence and homosexuality.
Kefauver served as Adlai Stevenson's running mate in 1956 when Stevenson lost the presidency for the second time to this popular ex-World War II hero.

Kefauver also investigated organized crime in a series of hearings in the 1950s. One of the many witnesses who testified was this man, known as the "Mob's Accountant." He fled Cuba as Castro took power and was eventually deported by Israel back to the US.

answers: Yosemite National Park [prompt on a park; prompt on California]
parts: Name this specific setting of that photograph, in which the elderly Imogen Cunningham peeps at the nude model Twinka Thiebaud (tee-BOH) standing behind a tree.
Cunningham was a member of this group of San Francisco-based photographers, alongside Willard Van Dyke and Edward Weston. Their name refers to an aperture setting on a large formal camera.

The nude photo of Twinka Thiebaud was taken at a workshop organized by this legendary photographer and member of Group f/64. He took many pictures of Yosemite National Park and captured a famous shot of Moonrise, Hernandez, New Mexico.

answers: Genoese crossbowmen [or crossbowmen from Genoa; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name these medieval archers who often served as mercenaries. They were routed by English longbowmen at the Battle of Crécy when the rain soaked their strings and rendered their weapons useless. Name both the region and specific type of unit.
This elite group of Norse fighters in the Byzantine army was formed when Basil the Bulgar-Slayer had his sister Anna married off to Vladimir the Great in exchange for their service.
These often-outnumbered medieval peoples heavily depended on their cavalry in battle. They resided in a region on the northern coast of France and won the Battle of Hastings.

answers: the death of God [accept equivalents including "God is dead"]
parts: Name this "greatest deed" that is announced by a madman holding a lantern who wonders if it will cause us to "plunge continually" in every direction.
The phrase "God is dead" is uttered in this work that, like its author's other work Daybreak, contains many sections arguing for individual self-expression over Judeo-Christian morality.
The Gay Science was written by this German philosopher. He contrasted Apollonian and Dionysian art in The Birth of Tragedy.

answers: Duat [or Tuat; or Tuaut; or Akert; or Amenthes; or Amenti; or Neter-kherket; prompt on the Egyptian underworld]
parts: Name this location where some people were consumed by Ammit if they failed a test involving an object belonging to Ma'at.

In the test, this body part of dead Egyptians was weighed and compared to the feather of Ma'at. If this body part weighed more than the feather, they were devoured for having insufficient truth and justice.
The god Thoth also hung out in Duat. He was typically depicted as having the head of either a baboon or this other animal.

answers: Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Children's Crusade: A Duty-Dance with Death <Collins>
parts: Name this story in which Billy the Poet, a "nothinghead," rapes a hostess at an Ethical Suicide Parlor. It takes place in a society in which the government hands out "ethical birth control" drugs to suppress people's sexual desires.

"Welcome to the Monkey House" is the title story of a collection by this author. His novel Player Piano follows Paul Proteus, an engineer in the fictional city of Ilium, New York, where he set many of his novels.
Vonnegut wrote this 1969 novel that chronicles the life of Billy Pilgrim, who becomes "unstuck in time."

answers: Federal Republic of Germany [or Bundesrepublik Deutschland]
dragonfly [or damselfly, prompt on insect; prompt on arthropod] <Fulgenzi>
parts: Name this avian genus discovered in 1861 from a single feather. The most famous example, the Berlin Specimen, was sold by its discoverer Jakob Niemeyer in order to purchase a cow.
Archaeopteryx was discovered in the Solnhofen limestone of this country. It contains the Aachen (AH-khen) Formation.

The Solnhofen limestone contains Aeschnogomphus (esk-no-GOM-fus) and Tharsophlebia (thar-so-FLEB-ia), examples of these animals. They are currently in the clade Odonata, and the Meganeura example had a two-foot wingspan.

answers: Antonio del Pollaiolo [or Antonio di Jacopo Pollaiuolo; or Antonio Pollaiuolo] <Bentley>
parts: Leander is awash in a stormy sea in this artist's early painting of Hero and Leander. The painting features many of this Flemish artist's signature fleshy nudes, also exemplified in The Raising of the Cross.

This saint has fallen off in front of his horse in a painting at Yale by Garofalo. Caravaggio's version of the same scene has this recently converted Christian raising up his arms at his horse's hindquarters.

Heracles, separated by a stream, prepares to shoot an arrow to rescue his wife from a centaur in a badly preserved Yale painting by this artist. This son of a chicken seller is famed for his Battle of the Ten Nudes.
Charles Nordhoff and James Hall wrote a 1932 novel about the mutiny against William Bligh on this ship. The novel took the point of view of the fictional narrator Roger Byam.
This author wrote the novel The Caine Mutiny in which the paranoid Captain Queeg is overthrown. He used his World War II experiences to write The Winds of War and War and Remembrance.
This 1840 memoir features no mutinies, but was written to protest the treatment of common sailors. Its protagonist serves aboard the Pilgrim and the Alert.

The Heine–Borel theorem states that a set of real numbers is compact if and only if it is bounded and has this property. Intervals with this property are denoted with square brackets to indicate that they contain both endpoints.
This doubly-eponymous theorem in analysis asserts that any bounded sequence of real numbers has a convergent subsequence. It implies the Heine–Borel theorem.

Any compact metric space can be written as the image of a continuous function from this nowhere-dense set. If N is the natural numbers, then this set is homeomorphic to 2 to the N, and thus it is compact according to Tychonoff's theorem.
